properties.text:
2015

July – 10.-15. Nuremberg, Germany – Wiki page with details (still room for more participants)

September – 21.-25. Frankfurt, Germany – Doodle

There are plenty of code sprints coming up, some of them already have specific dates while others are just in general planning mode. If you'd like to participate in one of them please feel free to fill out a doodle to show your interest.

Practical information
  • The code sprints are open to anyone as long as they can work primarily independently on the core parts of the product. We need help in all kinds of areas, so there's something for anyone being that development, documentation, testing, design, project management etc. However you should get in touch with us if you're interested in joining at hello@neos.io

December

In December 2013 a very special code sprint was organized to finalize the release of Neos 1.0. The code sprint was organized by Andreas Förthner and took place at his offices at Netlogix in Nürnberg, Germany. About 15 people attended the sprint and managed to release just in time for the release party scheduled at December 10th 18:00.

  • Wiki Page
  • Release parties

October

In October the team met in Frankfurt, kindly hosted by DE-CIX, who not only sponsored the meeting room but also the accommodation for all participants - thanks a lot! 24 people from 7 countries attended the sprint and worked together on Neos, most of them for the full 5 days of the sprint, resulting in over 150 merged fixes and features. Sebastian prepared a nice video with impressions from the code sprint.

  • Wiki Page

May

In May 2013 a code sprint took place at punkt.de in Karlsruhe, Germany, where we worked on the work packages and discussed some topics for the stable release. The goals were to find solutions for all the technical questions that were still unclear and to have clearly defined goals for the stable release.

  • Google+ Event Page
  • Wiki Page

We published some blog posts based on discussions during the sprint:

  • Neos and Flow - An update for the team structure
  • Putting Neos technology into usable form

October

Not long after the august code sprint the team met again, this time in Rødby, Denmark. This time we had a special location in form a very large manor, where working location and accommodation was combined. In total 28 participants took part making it the largest code sprint we've had so far. Organized by Aske Ertmann the code sprint welcomed 7 new contributors. Main topics of the sprint was finalizing 1.2, translation of UI and access controls.

  • News Article
  • Wiki Page
  • Unofficial blog posts from Sebastian Helzle, Dmitri Pisarev, Rens Admiraal & Henjo Hoeksma – Part I, Part II, Part III, Part IV & Part V

February

The first code sprint following the release of 1.0 took place in Lübeck, Germany and was organized by Robert Lemke. The focus of the sprint was to improve performance of Neos & Flow. It was a small sprint with 8 participants, however the outcome in terms of gains in performance improvements was big.

  • Wiki Page

March

Not long after the previous sprint the team met again, this time in Rosenheim, Germany. In connection with the Inspiring Conference the team met up before the conference for a few days at Rosenheim University. This was a large code sprint with 19 participants who worked on features for 1.1 and finishing performance improvements.

  • News Article
  • Wiki Page

June

Just before the developers days in Eindhoven, The Netherlands, the team met for a medium sized sprint with 13 participants. Organized by Rens Admiraal the sprint took place the the Technical University of Eindhoven (TU/e). Main topics was finalizing and releasing 1.1, which was released an hour before the developer days kicked off.

  • News Article
  • Wiki Page

August

After the summer holidays the team met up again in the end of august in Kiel, Germany. Organized by Christopher Hlubek the sprint had 13 participants. Main topics for the sprint was to finish features going into 1.2, improving stabilization and discuss various topics.

  • Wiki Page

Although people from all over the world are working remotely on Neos, a lot of progress was reached at real-life events. They are not only great for discussions and decisions, but also for developing at light speed.

Apart from working on Neos, code-sprints are also a great opportunity to meet and exchange with old and new friends.

As contributors and maintainers of this project, and in the interest of fostering an open and welcoming community, we pledge to respect all people who contribute through reporting issues, posting feature requests, updating documentation, submitting pull requests or patches, and other activities.

We are committed to making participation in this project a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of level of experience, gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, personal appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, age, religion, or nationality.

Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:

  • The use of sexualized language or imagery
  • Personal attacks
  • Trolling or insulting/derogatory comments
  • Public or private harassment
  • Publishing other's private information, such as physical or electronic addresses, without explicit permission
  • Other unethical or unprofessional conduct.

Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct. By adopting this Code of Conduct, project maintainers commit themselves to fairly and consistently applying these principles to every aspect of managing this project. Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct may be permanently removed from the project team.

This code of conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces when an individual is representing the project or its community.

Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported by opening an issue or contacting one or more of the project maintainers.

This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant, version 1.2.0, available from http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/2/0/

Contributor

Those community members who would like to get involved into the respective project are invited to start contributing code, design, documentation or provide help by other means. No one needs to ask for permission to get involved and start contributing as long as they can identify with our core values and technical principles.

Our more experienced contributors will help new contributors with the first steps in our forum and in our Slack channels. Anyone who contributes to the project is called a Contributor.

A Contributor …

  • will get credit in a list of contributors for the respective product they worked on.
  • can push changes to Gerrit and review change sets but cannot submit code to master.
  • is - technically - not (yet) part of the Neos Team.

Team Member

A team member regularly contributes high-quality code, documentation, design work, or something similar. Existing team members may invite a contributor to join them as a team member through consensus-based decision.

A Team Member ...

  • has deep knowledge of the product.
  • provides recent, recurring, high quality contribution.
  • is eligible for a @neos.io email address.
  • has basically full access and administrative rights to the git repositories, websites, social media accounts etc. like any other member of the team.
  • uses these access rights with great care and responsibility.
  • represents the project responsibly and prefers to solve disputes or disagreements within the team.

Neos and Flow, originally started by Robert Lemke and Karsten Dambekalns, are built by an ever-growing community of volunteers. The direction and organisation of the project is taken care of by the Neos Team, a group of highly committed long-term contributors who live Neos day in and day out.

 But team members are not the only people who are contributing; many users and other project supporters are helping Neos to grow through a steady stream of high quality contributions.

Feel inspired and invited to join us - even if you only start by fixing a bunch of typos in our documentation!

properties.caption: Contributors and team members alike worked hand in hand during a Neos codesprint in Copenhagen
properties.alternativeText: TYPO3 Neos team members and contributors

properties.text:
We, the team working on Neos and Flow, would like to be able to grow. We want to make it easy for new contributors to join us in building the coolest CMS built on our top notch PHP framework.

We also want to make sure everyone is recognized for their contributions. It should be natural to recognize both active and inactive contributors while we keep the team at a manageable size.

Finally, projects like Neos have plenty of things that need to be organized. Since they've got to be done, we want to give a group of people responsibility for these organizational tasks. To make all of this possible, we have set several groups and roles.

The members of the Neos Team base their work, communication and being together on core values like humility, respect, responsibility, and trust.

We try to remove all technical barriers and refrain from creating fine grained rule sets and procedures because we trust team members to use their rights and power responsibly.

The team follow these guiding principles: common sense and good intentions.

There is a dedicated page explaining our core values.

A remark about project leadership: The team pretty much manages itself, so there is no single project leader having the last word on each and every decision. Everyone on the team can be asked and each team member can take decisions. This works, because we value trust and at the same time everyone is humble enough to ask others on the team if in doubt.

Product Strategy

The overall strategy for our products Neos and Flow is jointly defined by the Neos Team. In the future we plan to establish a Product Strategy Group which will take over this task and, like other groups in the Neos community, agrees on a lead person.

Release Manager

The production of each minor or major version of Neos and Flow is coordinated by a Release Manager, which is elected by the Neos Team.

We summed up all important facts about release management on a dedicated page.

Community Group

The Community Group lends an ear to the needs of users, existing and potential contributors and solves possible disputes. This group also plans what's necessary to grow the Neos community make it a great place to be around.

Currently Christian Müller is our community contact.

Public Relations Manager

The Public Relations Manager coordinates the promotion of Neos with the Marketing Group, acts as a press contact, pushes news and takes care of the product website.

Currently Berit Hlubek is our public relations manager.

Treasurer

The treasurer acts as a budget owner and coordinates all efforts regarding funding and raising of funds for the Neos project.

Currently Sebastian Kurfürst is our treasurer.

Are you a skilled designer, developer, editor, manager, communicator or have an unusual talent which is missing in our team?

We'll gladly help you to get started and become a contributor by mentoring and sharing our experiences with you.

To get started, start playing with Neos and Flow, then come talk with us via our slack channel. For more hints on how to start contributing to the project, check out our contribution page.

Humility

We all make mistakes. Constructive criticism is always welcome.

Respect

We all have different opinions, different personalities, and different ways to approach problems.

Responsibility

We consider the consequences of our actions, our code, and our communication.

Trust

We trust other team members to make the right decision even when we are absent.

We are members of the Neos team. Each one of us is unique. But we share a set of values that make it fun to work as a team. These are our values. They motivate us and light our internal fire. Our values guide how we communicate and how we make decisions. We are agile. This is who we are.

This is living stuff that describes a living team full of living people. We are alive. We can clarify or adapt anything here to better reflect who we are. This stuff is not rules or procedures. We recorded these thoughts October 2013 at the Neos Codesprint in Frankfurt.

Humility

We love to learn from each other.

Respect 

We are passionate about creating great software.

Responsibility 

We value quality and excellence over mediocre but fast achievements.

Trust

We strive to improve ourselves and the project.

Humility

We discuss vividly, and we do not take it personally.

When I have something to discuss, I bring it up.

I won't take credit for efforts which are attributed to others.

Respect

We disagree, but we do not start flame wars.

When I disagree with you, I will talk with you respectfully.

Responsibility 

Outside the team, we are unified in our communication.

Our communication is consistent.

Trust

We trust each other to speak for the team.

When I present or speak, I speak for the team, not just for my own benefit. I might be a team delegate, and I might look like a team leader to people outside the team, but I recognize that there are no fixed team roles, and I respect my fellow team members.

Humility

We can learn from each other. We make decision processes transparent.

It is okay to reverse the decisions of others. No one can expect to get their way every time.

Respect

We listen to and value each other's arguments and feedback.

Seek the input of others.

Responsibility

We give each other permission to make decisions, and we expect each other to make those decisions quickly and responsibly.

Use common sense instead of fine-grained rules.

Trust

We trust all team members to make decisions. We trust each other to decide with good intentions.

Not everybody needs to be involved to make decisions.

Humility

We might make mistakes, but we take small steps. We can always adjust our course.

It is okay to reverse the decisions of others.

Respect

We celebrate both joint and individual achievements. We respect each team member as a person, not just for the role they are filling right now.

Acknowledge others and give credit where credit is due.

Responsibility

We move forward quickly. We make decision processes transparent.

No official team roles or hierarchy. No bureaucratic procedures.

Trust

We might use informal polls, but we do not have a formal voting process.

Not everybody needs to be involved to make decisions.

These people are members of the release team:

  • the Release Manager of each maintained release branch
  • the Team Leader
  • the Quality Manager

The Release team has these responsibilities:

  • Define and maintain the release process.
  • Decide which features match the product vision.
  • Plan and execute security releases with the Security Team.

There are four phases in the release process:

  1. Communication
  2. Preparation
  3. Release
  4. Finalization

News articles and other announcements should be written in the communication phase, and published in the finalization phase.

The preparation phase deals with any technical steps that need to be done before running the Jenkins release job, such as creating any new branches in git. Then, the Jenkins release job does the heavy lifting to tag the release, generate tarballs, push them to SourceForge, and a variety of other tasks that go into doing a release.

The Release Manager should be able to access the latest version of our Release Process document (All team members should have access to the latest version of this document which is currently stored in Google Drive.).

This page provides an overview of how we approach releases. This is a reference document for anyone interested in our releases, but is especially useful to help release managers understand their role in this process. The Release Lifecycle is managed by the Release Manager who is a member of the Release Team. The Release Team defines the Release Process. Each of these topics is described here.
Note: Both Neos and Flow have the same release lifecyle and release process. As both projects are managed by the same team, the release manager role works the same for both projects. Essentially, the release team includes release managers from both products instead of having a separate "team" for each.

There are two kinds of releases for Flow and Neos (Releases should use semantic versioning semver.org):

  • A new release is a release on a new release branch such as 2.0 or 2.1. (Semver.org: Major and Minor level versions)
  • A bugfix release is a release on an existing release branch such as 2.0.5. (Semver.org: Patch-level version)

In general, this is how we decide when to do a new release:

  • Release as soon as one or more major features is complete, including documentation.
  • Release within half a year after the last release, even if no major features have been completed.

Minor features can be included/merged in any new release but not for a bugfix release. Documentation for these features should be included.

We want bugfix releases to be automatic (if possible) or at least, they should happen frequently. The release manager is responsible for making sure these bugfix releases happen frequently, as required.

We only support, with bugfix releases, the latest release branch and one release previous to the latest release branch. However we try to make migrating from release to release as smooth as possible. Depending on the severity, we can also release security bugfix releases for older releases, but don't guarantee that we will.

A Release Manager is responsible for a release branch that includes a specific new release and all of its bugfix releases (i.e. The Release Manager for 2.0 is responsible for 2.0.1, but not 2.1). The Release Manager is responsible, throughout the maintenance lifetime of their specific release branch, for the following things:

  • Schedule and coordinate contributions for a specific release branch and all of its bugfix releases.
  • Prevent feature creep within the release branch by having a vision of what features can or should be included in the release.
    • The release manager has the final say on which changes can be included in the release.
  • Make sure that any major features are included in release notes before the feature is merged into the release.
  • Collaborate with the community contact and public relations manager to:
    • communicate the timeline and release branch vision,
    • write and distribute release announcements, and
    • other release specific communication.
  • Be available to answer questions about whether or not to include a change in the release branch.
  • Make sure releases happen, including the release branch's new release and all bugfix releases (See "The Release Process" below).

For Neos 1.0 the release manager is Sebastian Kurfürst.
For Neos 1.1 the release manager is Christian Müller.
For Neos 1.2 the release manager is Aske Ertmann.
For Flow 3.0 the release manager is Bastian Waidelich.
For Neos 2.0 the release managers are Aske Ertmann and Christian Müller.

Release Date: December 10, 2013
Neos 1.0 is the first stable release and happened right before a series of release parties all over the world on December 10th.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: December 3, 2013
Neos Beta 2 brought us even closer to the countdown of the final release on December 10th. This release included many improvements for making it possible for the integrator to be in control of the output from Neos. Besides that it included many bug fixes and stability improvements as well as the possibility to configure whether or not having pages ending with .html.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: December 13, 2013
Neos 1.0.1 is the first patch level release of the 1.0 branch. It was released three days after the first stable release and includes several bugfixes and minor improvments, mainly within the TYPO3.Neos package and inside the demo page.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: March 3, 2014
The release of Neos 1.0.2 delivers several bugfixes mainly within the package TYPO3.Neos as well as some fixes for TYPO3.TYPO3CR and some minor features.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: November 12, 2013
Neos beta 1 marked the countdown to the final release on December 10th. This release included most of the remaining features that will go into 1.0. We especially emphasized on getting all breaking changes in to make it as easy as possible to update from the beta to the final release. It included some new features like node references, allowing site root to contain content, customizable output, easier creation of content elements as well as various improvements.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: November 14, 2014
The third release of Neos focuses on adding translation support, improving the editor experience and implementing many new features. 92 new features, 265 tasks and 232 bugfixes make up the progress since the release of 1.1. 

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: November 26, 2014
The second beta release includes two important fixes that solves issues with moving nodes and linking to nodes/assets in inline editing. Additionally contains some UI improvements, minor additions and bugfixes.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: December 11, 2014
This release includes a fix for a regression introduced with Flow 2.2.1 that affected file uploads in the media module. On top of that it contains more fixes that have been merged since version 1.1.1.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.
Additionally a bunch of teasers can be found here.

Release Date: December 03, 2014
The third beta release includes three important fixes that makes it compatible with PHP 5.3 again, kickstarting new sites and exporting sites. Additionally contains some UI improvements, minor additions and bugfixes.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: January 2, 2015
This release contains some improvements and fixes several issues including an issue the new link editor, an issue with site import and an issue with moving of nodes.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: February 5, 2015
This release fixes several issues including the "Raw content" editing mode and 25 other issues as well as some minor improvements.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: March 26, 2015
This release fixes several bugs including a caching issue Internet Explorer, some content editing issues, an issue with the menu being closed unexpectedly & an issue with kickstarted sites. In total 40 bugfixes as well as some minor improvements. Additionally it contains a security fix considered to have a low severity. There is one change that could be breaking in case the database has some broken state where two nodes exists with the same identity.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: April 17/18, 2015
Includes a bunch of important fixes & improvements and corrects some unfortunate regressions in the last release. In total 27 bugfixes, including a few potentially, although unlikely, breaking ones.

A mistake was made causing stable installations to pull in unstable versions of some of the packages. If you have created a installation using 1.2.1–1.2.3 you need to adjust your "composer.json" file manually to prevent that. To do that you can follow the instructions provided here, where you can also check if your "composer.json" looks correct. All new installations won't be affected though. Sorry for the inconvenience.

Additionally the follow issues have been fixed: import of demo site failed in some situations without any error, upgrading Neos lead to a broken backend (browser cache flushing was required), moving of nodes could make them disappear in some scenarios until publishing, inline delete icon was unresponsive for some content elements, menu content elements broke if they had no items, creation of new pages created URL path segments with uppercase characters.

One important change is that node paths are now always lowercase to avoid conflicts with mixed casing. If you have two nodes with the same path when lowercased on the same level, you'll have to adjust manually, however this should be a theoretical edge case.

Read the detailed list of changes in the 1.2.4 changelog & 1.2.5 changelog.

Release Date: May 10, 2015
This release fixes several issues including node type constraints broken in some occasions and 12 other issues as well as some minor improvements.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: May 13, 2015
These two beta releases mark the start of the beta phase of the biggest release of Neos and Flow so far. It includes major new features for security, media management, resource management and localisation. Read more about it in the release notes.

Release Date: May 30, 2015
This release fixes several issues and solves an issue where installation using composer didn't work.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: June 05, 2015
The third beta of our upcoming major version contains a bunch of important bugfixes, stabilizing various new features. Read all the details in our changelog

Release Date: August 12, 2015
This release contains major new features, including an enhanced rights management, cloud-support for media assets and a translated user interface. Read all about it in our changelog and the release notes.

Release Date: July 2, 2015
Maintenance release containing many bugfixes and adjustments.

See a  detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: August 13, 2015
Maintenance release containing several bugfixes and adjustments.

See a detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: June 3, 2015
This release fixes several issues including an important one fixing the backend breaking occasionally in latest Chrome stable due to a bug in Chrome (details).

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: April 11, 2014
After 265 commits, thousands of lines of code changed and 2 code sprints, the first beta version of Neos 1.1 is released. A total number of 30 contributors, dedicated team members and a supportive community made this release possible.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: June 19, 2014
For the 1.1 release of Neos, we wanted to build a strong foundation for the major features that we are preparing for future releases. As such, we focused on stability and performance improvements.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: April 15, 2014
Neos 1.1 Beta 2 is the second beta release of the upcoming 1.1 version.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: May 27, 2014
Neos 1.1 Beta 3 is the second beta release of the upcoming 1.1 version.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: August 26, 2014
The first bugfix release of the 1.1 branch includes a lot of bug fixes mainly to content editing. It was released during a Neos Code Sprint in Kiel, together with Flow 2.2.1.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: September 2, 2014
This release includes a fix for a regression introduced with Flow 2.2.1 that affected file uploads in the media module. On top of that it contains more fixes that have been merged since version 1.1.1.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: March 27th, 2015
This release includes 65 bugfixes including two potentially breaking changes if node data is corrupted, e.g. if the database has two nodes exists with the same identity.. Other important bugfixes include one for Internet Explorer and one for the menu button. Additionally it contains a security fix considered to have a low severity.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: April 17, 2015
Maintenance release including 8 fixes including: upgrading Neos lead to a broken backend (browser cache flushing was required), menu content elements broke if they had no items.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: June 3, 2015
This release fixes several issues including an important one fixing the backend breaking occasionally in latest Chrome stable due to a bug in Chrome (details).

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: May 30, 2015
This release fixes several issues and solves an issue where installation using composer didn't work.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: July 2, 2015
Maintenance release containing several bugfixes and adjustments.

See a detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: August 13, 2015
Last maintenance release for the 1.1 branch including a couple of bugfixes and adjustments.

See a detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: October 22, 2013
Neos Alpha 6 contained lots of improvements, where most of them were incorporated during the code sprint at DE-CIX in Frankfurt. Main highlights were improved content editing, Plugin Views, features in TypoScript, a new demo site, improved security and lots of bugfixes and stability improvements.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: October 30, 2013
Neos Alpha 7 contained a couple of improvements, as being listed in the release notes. This was the last Alpha release of Neos.

Release Date: August 7, 2013
Neos Alpha 5 featured lots of smaller improvements, as being listed in the release notes.

Release Date: July 7, 2013
Neos Alpha 4 featured lots of great improvements, as being listed in the release notes.

Release Date: February 16, 2013
Alpha 3 concentrated on stabilizing the content editing and UI of Neos. Additionally some groundwork for future features was put into place. All changes since alpha 2 are listed in the changelog.

Release Date: December 19, 2012
Read the changes since alpha 1 to be informed about this release.

Release Date: October 5, 2012
The first Alpha of Neos was presented and released at the European T3CON 2012 in Stuttgart.

To update an existing installation to the latest patch release you can update the packages this way:

composer update --no-dev "typo3/*"
# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
./flow doctrine:migrate

By using composer, you can switch to the most recent master, in order to test the latest changes:

cd /installation-root/
# update composer.json according to https://github.com/neos/neos-base-distribution/blob/master/composer.json
# actually update the packages
composer update
# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
./flow doctrine:migrate

Server Environment

Not surprisingly, you'll need a web server for running Neos. We recommend Apache or nginx (though IIS and others work too – we just haven't really tested them). Please make sure that the mod_rewrite module is enabled.

Neos requires a database supported by Doctrine DBAL. We currently ship database migration scripts for MySQL and PostgreSQL

PHP

Make sure you have PHP 5.5 or later available on your web server. Make sure your PHP CLI binary is the same version! If available, you should use PHP 5.6 as it improves performance compared to earlier versions. Generally, a newer PHP version is better.

The default settings and extensions of the PHP distribution should work fine, but it doesn't hurt checking if the PHP modules mbstring, tokenizer and pdo_mysql are enabled, especially if you compiled PHP yourself. You really should (not only because of Neos) turn off magic quotes in your php.ini (magic_quotes_gpc = off).

Make sure the PHP functions system(), shell_exec(), escapeshellcmd() and escapeshellarg() are not disabled in you PHP installation. They are required for the system to run.

For more information on the system requirements check the relevant part of the Flow documentation.

This page has instructions to install Neos with composer, which downloads Neos itself. If you don't want to use composer, then download an archive instead. After having installed either way, continue to set up Neos as explained further down.

Note: If you want to learn more about which versions we support, and how we decide when to do a new release, please see our All about Releases page. If you are looking for details on the development process, start at the Contribute page.

• Set up a virtual host inside your apache.conf, and then restart apache:
    NameVirtualHost *:80 # if needed

    <VirtualHost *:80>
        DocumentRoot "/your/htdocs/Neos-2.0/Web/"
        # skip the following line for development
        SetEnv FLOW_CONTEXT Production
        ServerName neos.demo
    </VirtualHost>
  • Add an entry to /etc/hosts:
    127.0.0.1 neos.demo
  • Go to http://neos.demo/setup and follow the on-screen instructions!
Continue with the setup step now.

Alternatively install the 2.1 release candidate or update an existing installation by following this guide:

php /path/to/composer.phar create-project -s beta typo3/neos-base-distribution Neos-2.1
