properties.source: Download Neos 1.2.12 as archive

properties.text:
Installing Neos from an archive is convenient if you just want to try Neos and for the first steps. If you want to dive deeper into Neos and create a real site with it, we recommend using the installation via composer, instead.

First download the archive for the Neos version you want to install. Then unpack the archive to your webserver document root directory and continue with the setup.

First install composer like this:

curl -s https://getcomposer.org/installer | php

Then go to your webserver document root directory and download the Neos base distribution with all the dependencies:

cd /your/htdocs/
php /path/to/composer.phar create-project --no-dev typo3/neos-base-distribution Neos-2.0

By using composer, you can update an existing installation to the a specific version, without having to create a new project:

cd /installation-root/

# Remove the following line from composer.json (if present)
"minimum-stability": "dev",

# Update the composer.json file
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-nodetypes:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neosdemotypo3org:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-kickstarter:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/flow:2.3.*"
composer require --no-update "doctrine/migrations:@dev"

# Update the packages
composer update

# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
./flow doctrine:migrate
./flow node:migrate 20140708120530 --confirmation TRUE
./flow node:migrate 20140326143834
./flow node:migrate 20140930125621
./flow node:repair

# If you're migrating from the 1.2-dev branch you might need these
./flow node:migrate 20140516221523
./flow node:migrate 20140723115900
./flow node:migrate 20141210114800
See the release notes for a list of breaking changes

For further information on what changed please take a look at the release notes.

By using composer, you can update an existing installation to a specific version, without having to create a new project:

# Make sure you create a backup of the database and files!

cd /installation-root/

# Remove the following line from composer.json (if present)
"minimum-stability": "dev",

# Update the composer.json file
composer remove --no-update "typo3/flow"

composer require --no-update "typo3/neos:~2.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-nodetypes:~2.0"

composer require --no-update "typo3/imagine:~2.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/twitter-bootstrap:~2.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/form:~2.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/setup:~2.0"

composer require --no-update "doctrine/migrations:~1.0"

# Optional packages
composer require --no-update "typo3/neosdemotypo3org:~2.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-kickstarter:~2.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-seo:~1.0"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-googleanalytics:~1.0"

# Development packages
composer require --no-update --dev "typo3/buildessentials:~3.0"
composer require --no-update --dev "mikey179/vfsstream:~1.5"
composer require --no-update --dev "phpunit/phpunit:~4.6"

# Remove deprecated packages
composer remove --no-update "typo3-ci/typo3flow"

# Update the packages
composer update

# Flush the caches
./flow flow:cache:flush --force

# Ensure you have correct database charset/collation to prevent issues with foreign key constraints
./flow database:setcharset

# Run code migrations all or specific ones (required for running migrations)
./flow flow:core:migrate

./flow flow:core:migrate --version TYPO3.Neos-20150303231600
./flow flow:core:migrate --version TYPO3.TYPO3CR-20150510103823

# Run database and node migrations (stops in-between)
./flow doctrine:migrate
./flow node:migrate --version 20141103100401 --confirmation TRUE
./flow doctrine:migrate

# Publish resources
./flow resource:publish
 
# TIP: If you experience issues with pages not working, try running the node repair command
./flow node:repair

# TIP: If you get stuck when applying the node migration "20141103100401", make sure you apply the code migration "TYPO3.Neos-20150303231600" or manually replace "TYPO3\Media\Domain\Model\ImageVariant" with "TYPO3\Media\Domain\Model\ImageInterface"
See the release notes for a list of breaking changes

For further information on what changed please take a look at the release notes and the changelog.

There are different ways of installing TYPO3 Neos. For having a first look at the CMS we provide an archive which you can easily download. If you want to dive deeper and start with your Neos project we recommend using composer instead.

The user interface of Neos (like all software based on the Flow Framework) is translated using message catalogs in the XLIFF format.

While XLIFF–being based on XML–can be edited by hand, this is not really the best way to work on actually translating a lot of text. Thus we use the web-based Crowdin platform (using their open source plan, so thanks to them!) to translate the message catalogs in the packages that make up Neos.

This page explains how the translation process works from two perspectives:

  • The translators point of view, those "just using" the Crowdin platform.
  • The developers point of view, looking into the integration process and how Crowdin projects are set up.

If you have feedback, feel free to get in touch with us!

Workflow

Technically, Neos is not one monolithic system, but made of a number of independent packages. This means, that translations are spread over those packages as well.

The translations are contained in XLIFF files (here is an example) and translated using Crowdin. Those files are called message catalogs.

To be available there, they need to be uploaded, something our continuous integration server takes care of in this job. It is triggered when something is changed in the source code.

Everyone can then use the Crowdin platform to work on the translations in the Neos project.

The finished translations are then downloaded and put into our version control system, again by a job on our CI server. This job checks the translation platform daily for changes that need to be fetched.

Now, head over to the Crowdin sign up and create yourself an account. I'll wait here.

Using Crowdin

The user interface of Crowdin seems rather easy to use, but to learn about the features and not miss on some helpful tricks, you should read their documentation.

We suggest to start with their Interface overview and then work your way through the Translation tutorial.

Languages

Currently Neos come with some languages pre-configured for the users to select from (Dansk, Deutsch, English, Español, Français, Latviski, Nederlands, Polski, Pусский, Svenska), but we have 30 languages set up as target languages in the Crowdin projects we maintain.

English is a bit special, since it is also the source language for translations, meaning it is the language any labels are created in first.

If your language of choice is not available as a target language, get in touch with us to have it included. As soon as a target language has made sufficient progress, it will be included in the out-of-the-box settings in Neos.

All available translations are shipped with Neos, so even if your language is not among the ones enabled by default, you can still add it via configuration (look for availableLanguages in the Neos settings.)

Projects

As mentioned, Neos is made of of several individual packages. To make your life easier, we put all the message catalogs into a single project on Crowdin.

There might be more projects around, though, for packages not bundled with the Neos base distribution. Just search on Crowdin if you are looking for more to translate…

Roles

When you join the Neos project on Crowdin, you will be a Translator. This role allows you to create translations and vote on existing suggestions. Every language should have at least one Proofreader. This role allows you to approve translations, allowing them to actually be included in the translated message catalogs.

But since we are still in an early phase (where speed matters and proofreaders are rare), all translations are included for now.

Testing translations

If you have been working on translations in Crowdin, one option is to wait until the CI job fetching them back into the source code has run again and then update. This will only work if you are using the dev-master version of packages, though. If you do not have the option to do that, you can instead use the Neos demo to check your translations.

Another option is to download the translations from Crowdin and unpack them manually into your local project. To do this, just look for the Download button on Crowdin and unpack the downloaded archive over your Neos installation. Now the latest XLIFF files are available locally.

Communication

In our community platform we have created a category to discuss translation related issues. That can be anything from the best word for a specific case to global agreement on terms in the project glossary. Make yourself heard!
It is great that you want to help with translating the Neos user interface into your language! To get you started, here is an introduction into the most important things you need to know.

Workflow

The translations in a package are contained in XLIFF files (here is an example) and translated using Crowdin. Those files are called message catalogs.

To be available there, they need to be uploaded, something our continuous integration server takes care of in this job. It is triggered when something is changed in the source code.

Everyone can then use the Crowdin platform to work on the translations in the Neos project.

The finished translations are then downloaded and put into our version control system, again by a job on our CI server. This job checks the translation platform daily for changes that need to be fetched.

Creating XLIFF sources

To make your code fit for translation, you need to replace any hardcoded output with translations and create an english message catalog that contains the source for all those translations. More information on XLIFF message catalogs is available in the Flow documentation.

Updating XLIFF sources

If you add something to a package that already has message catalogs, just look for the most appropriate place to add your label. Follow the pattern in the existing files when it comes to identifier assignment and just update the english XLIFF file with any new labels you need. For packages that are part of the Neos and Flow base distributions, the changes will be pushed to Crowdin automatically as described above.

Testing translations

If you work on your translations locally, by editing the XLIFF file manually or with the help of some other tool, you can see the results directly.

If you want to test the results of translating on Crowdin, you can download the translations from Crowdin and unpack them manually into your local project. To do this, just look for the Download button on Crowdin and unpack the downloaded archive over your installation. Now the latest XLIFF files are available locally.

Using Crowdin for your own package

Crowdin can be used for any other Flow package just fine. And you can use the tooling we created for our purposes as well. The BuildEssentials package (most probably you have it installed via composer anyway, it is named typo3/buildessentials) contains a folder Crowdin with some helper scripts. Just follow the instructions in the README.rst file.

You have a Flow package that you want to translate? And you wonder how to use Crowdin on those XLIFF files? To get you started, here is an introduction into the most important things you need to know.

I am a Neos (or Flow) user and everything seem to work fine after the move. Do I need to worry?

No. If you are a Neos or Flow user and just require our packages using Composer, the source of a package doesn't really matter. Packagist tells Composer where a package can be found. Whether sources are on GitHub or another server only makes a difference in terms of speed, since GitHub builds archives for releases that are used by Composer automatically instead of cloning directly.

During composer install I get errors about invalid commit hashes or objects being gone due to rewritten history. Why?

With the move to GitHub all commit hashes changed (we switched to the use of monolithic repositories for development at the same time). Your composer.lock file contains remote URLs as well as commit hashes of the installed state of each package - and those hashes no longer exist on the new remote URL. To fix this, you need to delete Packages/Libraries/composer/installed.json and run composer update afterwards. This will update all packages and create a working composer.lock file again.

I have a development setup for Flow/Neos. How do I switch to using GitHub?

A tool to help with doing this is available at https://github.com/neos/Neos.Contribute. The main work that needs to be done is adjust your composer manifest to require neos/neos-development-collection and neos/flow-development-collection. These "replace" (in the sense of Composer's replace) the Neos and Flow packages. And of course you need to fork those two repositories on GitHub and get used to pull requests instead of Gerrit.

I still have open changes on review.typo3.org, what happens to them?

We kindly ask you to move your own open changes to GitHub and make pull requests out of them. A helper tool as well as documentation for doing this manually are available at https://github.com/neos/Neos.Contribute. Just make sure to abandon changes you have moved (or want to give up) with a small comment indicating what the status is.

There was a CLA that had to be signed, but I can't find any mention of it anymore!?

We dropped the CLA requirement, just make sure you are fine with the use of GPL (for Neos) and MIT (for Flow) before you submit changes.

I use Beard and want to continue to pick changes onto my project… Any news?

As of Beard 1.1.4 it can pick from PRs, see https://github.com/mneuhaus/Beard/releases/tag/1.1.4

What will happen to review.typo3.org and git.typo3.org?

The packages maintained by the Neos team will all move to GitHub and made read-only on Gerrit. Probably they will be removed from there (and git.typo3.org), but there is no timeline for that yet. Flow and Neos packages maintained largely by individuals will probably move to GitHub as well, either to individual owners or to organizations like Flowpack. Gerrit itself will continue to be mantained by the server team of the TYPO3 project. The same is true for the Git server, since it is basically a "read mirror" for the Gerrit system.

What will happen to the open changes on review.typo3.org?

We ask everyone to move their own changes from Gerrit to GitHub (see above on how to do that). After some grace period (not yet decided) we will look at the changes still open and decide on whether we move them or if we just abandon them as well.

Why did you move to GitHub?

A lot of people saw the (uncommon) workflow Gerrit imposes on contributors as a blocker. At the same time a lot of people rave about how easy contributions are on GitHub. Even though this depends on individual experience and preferences, we still thought it would be good to move to make life easier for more (potential) contributors, possibly even those that just want to fix a typo inn the documentation. On top of that, the project visibility, availability of statistics see here and here) as well as tools and services (Read the Docs, Code Climate, Travis CI, …) around GitHub is just way better. More insights into the decision process can be found in the thread RFC: The GitHub Move – Vote Needed! over at discuss.neos.io.

properties.title: …about the move from Gerrit to GitHub

properties.text:
I want to contribute to the documentation, how?

Great! Just click edit on GitHub and start fixing small issues, or clone and work in the "Documentation" folder of a package. There is just one thing: Don't create PRs against the (read-only) single-package repositories, but use the "development collection" repositories (see above).

I want to contribute code, can I just click edit on GitHub and start fixing small issues?

Yes, sure! There is just one thing: Don't create PRs against the (read-only) single-package repositories, but use the "development collection" repositories (see above).

Some of your repositories have a "[READ-ONLY]" notice - don't you want contributions?

Of course we want (and need) your contributions. But development of those packages happens in monolithic repositories we call "development collections", so please create your pull requests against those (see above). The read-only repositories are split automatically from those monolithic repositories to feed the Composer/Packagist infrastructure and ease installation of single packages.

Empty commits used to mark migrations as applied are missing in the read-only repositories. Is that a problem?

The way we split the repositories (using git-subsplit, which uses git subtree split) those commits inevitably get lost, since they do not "affect" the split subtree. This should not be a problem though, since the Flows core:migrate command skips packages in the TYPO3 namespace by default.

All packages maintained by the Neos team are bundled in the Neos organisation on GitHub. Its members have read and write access to all repositories of the organisation and can create new repositories as needed. To keep things simple, there are no further teams or distinctions when it comes to permissions. The exception to prove the rule is the "Owner" role, which not everyone has. If there is anything you need which only an owner can do, contact us via #ops-team in Slack.

The repositories on GitHub are your average git repositories and the usual way of working with them applies. Again, of course there is an exception…

Some repositories for single packages (Flow, Fluid, Neos, TypoScript and others) are marked as read-only. These exist only to "feed" Packagist to enable installation of those packages via Composer. The development of those packages happens in monolithic repositories for Flow and Neos we call "development collections". Pull requests are created against those and whenever something is merged the read-only repositories are updated automatically.

Until the move to GitHub we used Gerrit and it's clearly defined review process for development. With the move to GitHub that has changed, but right now there is no clear decision yet as how we want to continue. If you want to contribute to that decision, head over to this discussion and make yourself heard!

We strive for a quarterly release cycle of Neos. The team will focus on key features for each release that will be prioritized from users feedback and actual project needs.

This page shall give an overview about the upcoming areas we will work on.

Having a stable framework on how we store content is crucially important. We know that while the content repository currently does a good job in many situations, there are cases where there are some problems: For example, when many editors concurrently edit the same content, it can happen that their override each other.

We're currently planning a major refactoring of the Content Repository internals, building upon the concepts of Event Sourcing and CQRS. This will enable more advanced features like undo/redo or soft deletion, and will greatly reduce the risk that two editors override changes of one another.

Now that basic content translations and other content dimensions work, we are having many ideas for more advanced translation features.

We'd like to build a split screen view which allows to display two different languages side-by-side; being able to compare between an original and the translated version.

Additionally, if the original content changed, it would be helpful for the editor to get a notification that a translation needs to be adjusted further.

While we have just started to integrate Google Analytics as the first external service, we would like to integrate more services. Especially for analytics and for assets, we want to work on expanding the list of supported external services.

Furthermore, we want to make sure that information stored in Neos is accessible to foreign services as well by providing extensible APIs.

From the very beginning, Neos rendering has been built to allow for rendering only parts of a web page. However, we do not expose this functionality to the user yet.

By allowing partial rendering from the outside, Neos  – in combination with Edge Side Includes and Varnish  – will allow to build highly customized experiences without sacrificing performance.

While we are able to work with multiple content appearances right from the start, we did not tackle customized content for each channel yet. We'd especially like to allow arbitrary conditions to be used in rendering; i.e. changing a header image depending on the current weather or the user's geographical location.

In order for responsive previews to work correctly inside Neos, the integrator needs to load special CSS to adopt the website a little if it is loaded inside Neos. We have some ideas how we could avoid that, rendering the previews exactly in the same way as the final user will see them.

Neos cannot be built without participation of many dedicated community members – we need your help to implement your favourite feature.

Just get in touch with us so we can bring you up to speed.

We'd like to improve the integrator experience by providing specialized developer tools which can be used to understand TypoScript and Fluid rendering, debug custom node types or show the system logs.

We also imagine a more graphical way to assemble node types, which hopefully will make it easier for new people to create their custom node types.

We know that content management of today is different than it was a few years ago. Dealing with high load, distributed services is very common. In Neos, we want to make our export/import functionality more versatile to use and also create a service that allows synchronization of content across different web sites.

Because of its robust foundations, clean abstraction layers and the use of universally unique identifiers (UUIDs), this is a lot easier to implement than with classical web applications.

The navigate component, which is one of the main controls to find the data to be edited, shall be made more flexible than it is currently. We want to make sure it works with huge amounts of data.

Additionally, there are data types where other display formats, like a stream or cards, might be more appropriate than the tree display which is possible today – that's why support for other kinds of representations shall be added.

For bigger websites, changes often need to be reviewed before they are published. While the TYPO3CR includes the technical foundations for this since some time, this is not exposed to the end-user.

We want to allow that changes are not published to a live workspace, but an intermediate review workspace.

In addition to that, we'll add a way to add comments to content, which can serve as sticky notes or a communication medium between different users.

We feel that Neos is not yet as easy to use for new people joining our community than we'd like it to be. That is why we would like to solve the most common roadblocks, like making sure that Neos runs on shared hosting.

Furthermore, we'll look at common integrator mistakes and improve these cases by providing better guidance on what the integrator can do in these cases.

While Neos has great in-place editing support, sometimes data should be edited in a more structured and formalized way, independent of a specific representation.

We want to add the possibility to edit content through forms or other structured editing controls in the content module, with the ability to add specific validation and rendering rules.

Additionally, we plan to further improve content editing  extensibility by switching to Aloha2.

The Neos team is improving the master plan of the Neos user experience while agencies all over the world are slowly beginning to do their own web sites using the alpha version of Neos. We have in Neos a beautiful baby - but it still needs to be taught manners and raised well.

So, the team has been asking itself the simple question: How will large labyrinthine organizations work with web sites in 2017? 

We’re also asking leading user experience and CMS experts from around the world the same question, getting them to challenge our thoughts.

…Plus, we’d love to hear the answers of everyone in the community!

properties.title: How do you think enterprises will build and maintain their complex sites in 2017?

properties.text:
If you’d like to take part in this discussion, please join the Neos forum and share your thoughts. The input we get will directly influence the way we plan future functionality of Neos.

We’ll share some of the inspirational thoughts that will appear throughout the process coming from both the TYPO3 community and outsiders.

properties.caption: Neos team discussing the structuring of the general user experience at the May '13 code sprint
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The master plan of the first production-ready versions of Neos is pretty set by now.

But as Neos is a CMS that will work especially well for the larger, more complex solutions, we’re looking for all the help we can get in prioritizing future features and how we structure the user interface to handle e.g. complex localization or digital asset management.

Read on if you’d like to get insight into the inner workings of the user experience plan.

The Neos team is putting together all the generic design interface specifications into a single document that will allow future designers and developers achieve a consistent user experience across any kind of plugin or module.

If you are an experienced application interface designer, this is therefore a perfect time to help out.

Write to hello[at]typo3[dot]org if you want to get in touch.

In only few years from now, the world will have entirely new cities. Cities whose development has not even started. Cities that can draw from all we know about livability and functionality. The same goes for websites. Major websites will be built with the tools we’re constructing today. But we don't know how they will be like. Just think of how different sites were 3 years ago.

For both cities and websites, one basic rule counts: Things are constantly changing and can never be fully anticipated.

The inspiration from urban planning permeates our UX master plan, giving us crucial guidelines for structuring everything we know  - and making room for all the future change we don’t know.

In 2017, Neos will have been in use for years as a trusted tool to build and maintain complex websites. Many extensions were added and ideas we cannot imagine today will have been added to the software.

Yet, today we need to decide on major parts of the experience and the interface. If everything is added on an ad hoc basis - because it just feels right to put a button here and a menu there - you would end up with slums of the interface.

We've planned the Neos backend like you plan cities - with lots of room for change. Regardless of you being an integrator, a developer, a content editor or a site manager, the overall experience of using Neos provides for a productive life inside the interface.

We’ve put emphasis on concepts, in line with the feature set, that will provide for great personalization of both the backend workflow and the web experience that publishers will be able to deliver. The principles we've chosen can guide later alterations to the interface.

1. Create boundaries: Clearly separate different kinds of components to make users know where to look.
  2. Thinking is King: It’s your thinking that determines the web experience for your users, not the CMS.
  3. Distribute capacity: Provide power when needed.
  4. Simulate before publishing: Experience what your users will experience.
  5. Plan for change: Make the interface adaptable to reorganizing.

2. Thinking is King

It’s your thinking that determines the web experience for your users, not the CMS

1. Create boundaries

Clearly seperate different kinds of components to make users know where to look

When we looked at the city as an analogy for websites, we looked for boundaries to help us structure the Neos backend. In cities, there’s a very hard boundary between private and public. With that thinking we made a plan for where things belong.

A street is not a home. You drive fast on highways, not on the sidewalks. Likewise, we’ve planned the backend experience to give everything a natural home in the interface and in workflows. A module is in the menu, a node of every type is in the new Navigate menu, meta-data is in the Inspector -  and you edit your content seamlessly in the content itself.

These major parts will function as our hard boundaries preventing flooding of the interface. Everything logically structured to make sure developers will know where to put new components - making users know where to find everything.

When planning a city, you need to think. Often, content management systems will tell you that they’ve done all the thinking for you.

In Neos, you’ll be able to build great websites with a CMS that doesn't impose a certain process or a particular business logic. Neos doesn’t compete with other software that makes it super-easy to build a quick blog or a photo gallery. It is meant for more complex solutions.

Yet at the same time, we use UI design principles from the world of easy-to-use web experiences. It’ll be up to you to decide how you work with it.

You can build a web application first, then later decide to use Neos as a thin layer of content editing on top - or the other way around. The interface must facilitate such variation of use.

3. Distribute capacity

Provide power when needed

The distribution of power in a city makes sure that everyone gets what they need. You don’t power a shed in the way you power a nuclear plant. The ultra-simple editing makes editors center their attention on content.

If you need to add SEO data next to the content, Neos has an inspector that opens up for that kind of functionality. Just a bit more power, one step at a time... If you need more, the inspector will be expandable to the full backend screen providing the user with all the options.

That’s not enough? Create custom backend modules. And if even that's not enough, underlying Neos, we have Flow - a first-class web framework that enables you to build web applications that integrate with your other systems.

We don’t get in your way. We just provide open, flexible, powerful tools and a mindset of how to work with them. Everything connected in interfaces that don't interfere with the process of your business.

4. Simulate before delivering

Experience what your users will experience

With Neos, you will be able to view and preview your content in different ways. Switch to fullscreen mode to experience exactly what your users will experience. If your designer is not finished with the design, you can also make content editors start working with content in wireframe mode and apply templates later.

If you want editors to preview how SEO metadata for a page will appear in a Google search, you should be able to extend the preview for the editor. Same goes for mobile preview, tablet or any other preview you need. The longer-term plan is to collect all these views in one View menu.

5. Plan for change

Make the interface adaptable to reorganizing

Cities change constantly - and websites do the same. We cannot fully predict how the web will work in the years to come. We're working hard to make the interface and the frontend development of the backend as flexible as possible.

As everything is logically structured in the backend, later rearrangements of the interface will be a lot easier.

The Neos team is putting together all the generic design interface specifications into a single document that will allow future designers and developers achieve a consistent user experience across any kind of plugin or module.

If you are an experienced application interface designer, this is therefore a perfect time to help out. Write to hello[at]typo3[dot]org if you want to get in touch.

Aske Ertmann & Rasmus Skjoldan

Neos (like the Flow Framework) is documented using the reStructuredText format and the Sphinx documentation renderer.

Using Sphinx everyone can render reStructuredText to HTML (and other formats), and we use the web-based readthedocs.org platform to generate rendered documentation for Flow and Neos.

This page explains how writing documentation works from a technical perspective.

If you have feedback, feel free to get in touch with us!

Workflow

The documentation for Flow packages is contained in the package itself, inside the Documentation folder.

If you check the Documentation Library you will see that our "official" packages are all rendered on readthedocs.org. They show up in the library because they are all maintained by the neos user there.

If you want to have your own documentation rendered publicly, the easiest way is to create an account at readthedocs.org (it's free!) and import your project there.

Adding documentation

The minimal structure needed for documentation is an index.rst file to put content into. Most of the time you also want to render that into HTML, so you need a conf.py file to tell Sphinx how to handle that. Having some extra directories to hold (potential) assets is the icing on the cake.

The easiest way to create that skeleton if you lack it, is to use the Kickstarter: ./flow kickstart:documentation

Editing documentation

You can just start editing the reStructuredText sources in the Documentation folder of your package.

To check the results you can install Sphinx and in the Documentation folder call make html to generate HTML output for you to check. If you run make livehtml you can even point your browser to http://127.0.01:8000 and see the updated documentation reload automatically when you change the sources.

If you are satisfied, create a nice commit and push it for review. Once it is merged, it will show up in the rendered documentation soon.

Communication

In our community platform we have created a category to discuss documentation related issues. Make yourself heard!
A great package deserves excellent documentation! To make your life easier this section shows you how to add documentation to a package.

properties.title: I want to improve existing documentation

properties.text: It is great that you want to help with improving the documentation of Neos or Flow! To get you started, here is an introduction into the most important things you need to know.

Workflow

Neos is made of a number of independent packages. Thus documentation is partly spread over those packages as well.

The documentation for Neos and Flow is contained in the Flow and Neos packages itself. There are other packages that have their own documentation (like the SEO addon or the Google Analytics integration). If you check the Documentation Library you will see that those are all rendered on readthedocs.org. They show up in the library because they are all maintained by the neos user there.

Editing documentation

You can just clone any package you want to contribute to and start editing the reStructuredText sources in the Documentation folder.

To check the results you can install Sphinx and in the Documentation folder call make html to generate HTML output for you to check. If you run make livehtml you can even point your browser to http://127.0.01:8000 and see the updated documentation reload automatically when you change the sources.

If you are satisfied, create a nice commit and push it for review. Once it is merged, it will show up in the rendered documentation soon.

Communication

In our community platform we have created a category to discuss documentation related issues. Make yourself heard!

This page lists only "official" packages and their documentation. If you have other pacjages, check their Documentation folder, it may contain more packages. Also, searching on readthedocs.org might turn up results. And if you still don't find the documentation you need, why not write it yourself?
Flow

Release branches

  • v3.0 API documentation
  • v2.3 API documentation

Development branch

  • master API documentation
Neos

Release branches

  • v2.0 API documentation
  • v1.2 API documentation

Development branch

  • master API documentation
The API documentation is generated from the source code automatically and is maintained for the supported branches and the development master.

The Neos CMS team is committed to user privacy. For statistical reasons we collect the following technical data:

  • type of browser
  • type of operating system
  • referrer URL
  • time and date of the use of the website
  • your IP address

This data is collected anonymously and will be kept separately from private user data, you might have to give us at this Website.
We might use cookies to keep your session active. A cookie is a little textfile, that is stored from your browser on your system. We do not use cookies for personal data recognition.

In some cases we need to collect your private user data, to process certain information on this website This data will not be give to any other third party without your explicit written notice.

In some cases we might be forced to give the data to official government agencies.
In case you want to know what data we collect on our servers, feel free to send us an e-mail to hello [at] neos . io

Neos CMS
E-Mail: hello [at] neos . io

VisdP: Berit Hlubek (berit [at] neos . io)

properties.title: Predicting and shaping the future of web content management

properties.text:
What kind of CMS tools and processes will be important in 4 years from now? How can we plan our software today so that it is highly relevant in years to come? Such questions are naturally essential to the planning of a new CMS, based on our experience of the +500.000 site strong TYPO3 CMS.

Here, experts like content strategist, Karen McGrane, vendor-neutral client advisors like Janus Boye and Perttu Tolvanen of North Patrol - as well as large CMS clients such as the Danish Broadcasting Corporation - have all given us their views on the future of content management.

On our way to the 1.0 release of TYPO3 Neos, the team building the open source CMS realized we had to take planning much further. We couldn't just focus on getting 1.0 ready.

That simple realization made us start curating this collection of forecasts. About how the web will be built in 2017.

properties.title: Hi future! How will the web be built in 2017?

properties.text:
We have spent a good deal of time asking leading experts in the field about how they see the future of WCMS. Mixing their great experience and knowledge with our own thoughts on how the WCMS field is changing, we now can better plan beyond our first production-ready release of TYPO3 Neos.

In company with this goal, we also wanted to tell the story about how much change is going on in the CMS world.

properties.source: <iframe src="http://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/24491044?rel=0" width="340" height="290" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" style="border:1px solid #CCC;border-width:1px 1px 0;margin-bottom:5px" allowfullscreen> </iframe>

properties.text:
Karen McGrane, Janus Boye, Alain Veuve, Perttu Tolvanen, Boris Kraft, Kian Gould, Martin Goldbach Olsen, Jacob Floyd, Mikkel Staunsholm, Olivier Dobberkau, Daniel Hinderink, Christian Badse, Robert Lemke, Jan-Erik Revsbech, Sebastian Kurfuerst, Anders Bendix Kiel, Christian Nilson, Rasmus Skjoldan

(Please note that all statements have kindly been given to us specifically for this collection.)

Apart from this collection of thoughts on the future, many things are going on in the continuous planning of TYPO3 Neos. We're quite far in establishing a client follow-group that will help us make sure that we are building a tool for real client needs and not just our own itches. We have been conducting interviews, workshops and meetings with leading experts - among others with Head of User Research at the UK Government Digital Service, Leisa Reichelt, Yat Hui of Urban Beings and Information Architects Inc.

Our development releases also showed a lot of the technical progress taking place - and the newly revised user interface, guided by our user experience master plan. With the release of the first production-ready version we also experience the launch of bigger real-life projects.

We hope many people will share and debate what some of the implications of these predictions may be. On Twitter using #neoscms or on the Neos forum and mailing list.

Questions about the 2017 WCM Forecast can be sent to Neos team at hello[at]neos.io.

Neos is still in the beginning of it's journey of creating a next-generation content management system. We're already preparing future releases that will make your experience even better. To stay updated about new releases, please subscribe to our announcement newsletter.

The following introduction video to Neos shows you how quick and easy it is to edit content. Part of the video is a demonstration on how to create pages, edit texts and insert and crop images as well as how publishing content changes works.

You can choose between an english and a german version of the screencast.

Can’t wait to try Neos but don’t want to spend time on installing it? Take a free test drive with a pre-installed version and experience the new feel of content editing:

  • Launchr offers a hosted Neos for testing purposes for free. Just sign-up and take off with Neos.
  • A 30-day trial hosting with a pre-installed Neos is offered by Mittwald.
  • Codecoon offers an one-click Neos Installer for Mac and Windows and a free Neos hosting for demo purposes.

If your company is also offering a test environment for Neos and you would like to be listed here, please get in touch with us.
Here are some first step-by-step instructions on how to learn Neos. We plan to expand this section in the future.

You can find the Neos Demo Site inside the
 …/Packages/Sites/TYPO3.NeosDemoTypo3Org
folder of your Neos distribution.

The Neos Demo Site follows all best-practices for Neos, so we suggest that you analyze and modify it.

Now, it's time to check out the Neos Documentation, most specifically:

  • The Getting Started guide explains the installation and the basics of the Neos UI.
  • The Neos How To's contains short solutions to many common requirements.
  • The Creating a Site with Neos chapter contains full explanations of TYPO3CR, TypoScript and the whole rendering process.
  • And then the other documentation in the Library

We need your help expanding the documentation! It is currently stored inside the Neos Git Repository; so you can push your suggested changes to review.typo3.org as usual.

If you need help in setting up everything you need, get in touch with the team and we can help you out.
Head over to the Download page for the installation instructions. As soon as you have Neos installed and ran the setup tool, you will have the Neos Demo Site available to play with.

properties.title: Are there any extensions available for Neos? Is there an extension repository?

properties.text:
The concept of extensions is a bit different in Neos than the one you might know from TYPO3. First of all, many projects based on Neos don’t need specific extensions because many features can be implemented through TypoScript in combination with the Neos Content Repository. But of course there are extensions, too – we call them “packages”. A package can contain everything, be it Neos plugins, new content types, TypoScript or even new features for TypoScript itself.

We estimate that there are a few hundred packages based on Neos and many of them can be found via packagist.org. The Neos team has plans for providing a Neos / Flow package repository on the project website and also started working on a simple implementation. As of April 2015 though this project has stalled because we currently need to invest the resources we have into the upcoming major releases of Neos and Flow.

properties.title: How can I use the semantic features in Neos? I can't find any hint in the user interface or editor.

properties.text:
Neos is semantic ready, as it is possible to create any markup you'd like inside your content element. Thus, creating content elements which adhere to microformats, RDFa or schema.org is a breeze.

Furthermore, CreateJS allows for future UI integration of semantic editing features. For details have a look at Rens' and Henri's presentation slides about CreateJS and Neos from T3CON12, or watch the recorded presentation.
We collected questions regarding installation and usage of Neos. Can't find your question on this page? Feel free to send us a message and we will help you out and add the question here.

Yes, Neos has a built-in cache system since version 1.1. The content cache stores rendered content and was designed for flexible use even in complex websites

You may want to use a caching proxy like Varnish in front of Neos for high traffic sites.

properties.title: Where can I find merchandise for Neos?

properties.text: There will be an official shop with several different products.

properties.title: What is the official hash tag for Neos?

properties.text: The hash tag we use for Neos and where we will also look for questions and other input is: #neoscms.

properties.title: Why can't Neos do this or that?

properties.text:
First off, we want to do everything right from the start. The idea is that whenever we release a feature it will be as bulletproof as humanly possible.

This ideal of course somewhat limits the amount of features we can put out at a time, but we put quality over quantity.

Furthermore, due to the big flexibility of Neos and Flow, it’s often possible to create new features as separate packages – so we need your help to build the features you need. If you feel a feature is missing and you’d like to build it, please get in touch with the team and we can provide you some guidance.

properties.title: Can I import my website from TYPO3?

properties.text:
We need to distinguish between content import and template/extension import.

Template/Extension import is not possible, and will never be. However, if you use Extbase and Fluid in TYPO3 CMS already, it will be easier for you to port this code to Neos.

Content import is currently not possible.

However, while we do not have content import ready as of today, we are already experimenting with different approaches of a content migration process and think that pages and the standard TYPO3 CMS content elements like Text or Image will be importable in the future. Additionally, we’ll make sure that the conversion process is extensible, so you can adjust it if you use special FCEs or the like.

You can download our Neos fact sheet. If you need a print optimized version just contact us.

Detailed information for the promotion of Neos at conferences and fairs will follow.
Download Neos Flyer [pdf | 598 kb]
This FAQ is designed to give you a quick overview of the information we have about the split.

Get connected

  • How can I stay up to date with the Neos team?
  • How can I contribute?
  • I want to support the Neos project financially - how can I help?
  • Will you join the TYPO3 Developer Days 2015?
  • How can I get in contact with the Neos team?
  • I need a certain Neos feature for a project. What can I do to foster that?

Project/Product Strategy

  • Why are you splitting and why now?
  • What will change with the split and when?
  • What will change concerning the brand?
  • Are there any changes to the Neos team?
  • What about Flow?
  • What is happening to Surf and Fluid?
  • What’s the relationship with the TYPO3 community?

Development and Contributions

  • What happens with the remaining Neos budget for 2015?
  • Will the split impact the development of Neos?
  • Do you continue to work on Neos 2.0 and Flow 3.0?
  • Will you still move to GitHub?
  • Will you still drop the CLA / move to MIT license?

We’ll publish regular news around the Neos project on our website. Furthermore, you can follow us on Twitter, where we’ll keep you updated through our @typo3neos account and with the #neoscms hashtag.

Also, make sure you have registered for our newsletter!

Thanks for asking! :)
We're currently working on revising our contribution workflows and guidelines. In the meantime we're organizing ourselves through Slack - so the easiest way to get started is registering a Slack account through http://slack.neos.io. On Slack, you’ll meet the core team and other community members and we’ll help to get you started.

If you want to contribute code or documentation, we’re still accepting patchsets using http://review.typo3.org as we did in the past. In the longer run, we will switch to GitHub - make sure you have registered for our newsletter to receive the latest news around Neos.

There will be some additional changes to the contribution process in the upcoming weeks and months, where we’ll update this FAQ accordingly.

properties.title: How can I stay up to date with the Neos team?
I want to support the Neos project financially - how can I help?

properties.text:
If you want to donate, we’re currently establishing a mechanism. We’ll update this FAQ when it is ready.
Until then, please get in contact with us via hello@neos.io.

properties.title: Will you join the TYPO3 Developer Days 2015?

properties.text: Yes, big parts of our team will be at the TYPO3 Developer Days 2015 and we are looking forward to meet you there!

properties.title: How can I get in contact with the Neos team?

properties.text:
If you have not been in touch with a Neos developer beforehand, currently the easiest way to get in touch is through slack or via hello@neos.io.
If you already know a Neos developer personally, just contact her/him directly.

properties.title: I need a certain Neos feature for a project. What can I do to foster that?

properties.text: We are happy to discuss your specific feature idea together with you -- and then find a way to arrange implementation. Get in touch via slack or via hello@neos.io.

properties.title: Why are you splitting and why now?

properties.text:
The TYPO3 team and the Neos team have realized more and more that TYPO3 CMS and Neos are two very distinct products, with different requirements, different underlying assumptions of how a modern CMS should be built and different target groups.

We want to be able to focus on Neos with all our energy, thus we decided together with the TYPO3 Association and the CMS team that a split would be the best way forward for both projects.

properties.title: What will change with the split and when?

properties.text:
The Neos team will continue to take full responsibility for the whole product, including marketing, communication, infrastructure and so on.

There are some changes we can outline already and we’ll publish updates as soon as we can

  • Neos and Flow will switch to GitHub
  • We will switch to our own top level domain (neos.io)
  • We created our own slack group for project communication
  • Documentation will be rendered using ReadTheDocs
  • We want to drop the CLA and switch Flow to the MIT license

properties.title: What will change concerning the brand?

properties.text:
We will keep the Neos name without the TYPO3 prefix.
As a twitter hashtag, we will use #neoscms.

properties.title: Are there any changes to the Neos team?

properties.text: No. The Neos team is still the same team as before and we are extremely committed to Neos.

The Flow Framework is underpinning Neos, so it is a crucial component to the success of Neos. Just as before, we are committed to steadily improving Flow and its documentation and have lots of ideas for further features.

properties.title: What is happening to Surf and Fluid?

properties.text: Surf and Fluid are important parts of the Neos ecosystem and we’re committed to maintaining them.

properties.title: What’s the relationship with the TYPO3 community?

properties.text: All people from the Neos team have many individual connections and friendships throughout the TYPO3 community and the TYPO3 CMS team. We are certain that these connections and friendships will continue to positively influence both projects.

properties.title: What happens with the remaining Neos budget for 2015?

properties.text: The TYPO3 Association owns the budgets and has to decide what will happen with it.

properties.title: Will the split impact the development of Neos?

properties.text:
No. 
At least not in any negative way. We plan to improve our infrastructure and become more open, transparent and agile to make it easier to contribute and participate in the Neos community.

properties.title: Do you continue to work on Neos 2.0 and Flow 3.0?

properties.text:
Yes.
The first Neos 2.0 beta has just been released and can be downloaded:

  • Neos 2.0 Beta download
  • Release article for Neos 2.0

properties.title: Will you still move to GitHub?

properties.text:
Yes, we’re still preparing the migration to GitHub. We believe this will make contribution much easier and lay the foundation for growing the Neos community.

Update: The move to GitHub has been done, see the announcement.

properties.title: Will you still drop the CLA / move to MIT license?

properties.text:
Yes, we still want to drop the CLA. Flow will move to the MIT license, Neos will remain GPL. Currently, we are figuring out a way to go forward with the license change.

Update: The license switch has been agreed to by the TYPO3 Association. The code (and other mentions of the license) will be adjusted in the near future.

Neos enables you to export and import website content. You can easily move content between development, staging and production.

Additionally, Neos is deployable through Surf – the standard deployment solution for Neos and Flow. Surf makes changes to functionality in your projects reproducible and highly reliable.

Requirements will change during the lifecycle of your project. This is why we put a lot of effort into making Neos as flexible as possible, while presenting a purpose-built, clean interface.

For more advanced use-cases you can use the power of the Flow application framework to add new functionality.
Deane Barker from gadgetopia.com shares his thoughts about our new CMS after a demonstration of Neos:
Karen McGrane, the author of Content Strategy for Mobile, gives her impression of Neos:

Think of Neos as an open source Content Application Platform based on its own PHP framework Flow. A set of core Content Management features is resting within a larger context that allows you to build a perfectly customized experience for your users.
Read full release notes of the current release
Download Neos 1.2

Neos 1.2

Ubiquitous Content just arrived. Neos 1.2 has been released and Neos 2.0 started the Beta phase.

The most basic way of editing content in Neos is available by just clicking what you want to change, working out the changes and pressing the publish button. It's that simple. 

If you need to edit SEO data next to the content, Neos provides an inspector for that.

If you need more, the inspector will be expandable to the full screen providing the user with all property options.

That’s not enough? You can create custom backend modules in a snap.

Neos will blend in seamlessly with your website so you as an editor don't have to re-think in order to edit your content. It is our philosophy to reduce the amount of cognitive load to make editing content fun again.

You don‘t need training to edit content in Neos – you already know how to do it. You just click on the part you want to edit – and start. But since publishing projects have very different authoring needs, there is no only way of editing content in Neos.

Either use the full In-Place editing or use what we call Raw Content editing. Raw Content is like having a distraction-free authoring application right inside your CMS – where all the templates are stripped away.

Raw Content mode also makes reusing content across channels more efficient because editors don't spend time perfecting content to match the template. Instead they can focus on the pure words and images while working with a tailored authoring interface.

The Preview Central is where you build your preview templates. If you want your editors to always check three different representations of their content before publishing, then this is easily done in Neos.  

The Preview Central is right next to your editing modes in Neos. You can quickly switch back and forth between editing and previewing.

When you create responsive websites, your CMS should naturally aid you by being responsive as well.

Your websites will load faster, feel more fluid and generate a better user experience than websites built with any other CMS on the market.

Since the advanced content editing mechanisms in Neos work together with your website you can change your contents directly within a responsive viewport – getting immediate results and reducing the time of testing your contents on different devices.

Apart from that Neos does not force you to build your website in a special way. Just create your templates - Neos will take care of the rest.

Since Flow is cloud-ready, so is Neos. Neos scales with your business and your demands. You plan an intense marketing campaign? Simply add as many servers as needed to your environment.

This is all made possible with TYPO3 Surf, enabling zero-downtime deployment and making it easy to set up identical servers.

Outrun the competition using Neos' advanced semantic features.

With Neos, creating custom content elements is a breeze - with whatever markup you need. So go ahead and embed RDFa, Microformats or schema.org attributes inside your templates - whatever fits best to your use-case.

Being built on its own PHP framework  – Flow – makes your systems easy to adapt for whatever the future holds in store.

Flow provides built-in security, keeping your developers focussed on their main task - building your application - without having to worry about low level implementations.


The „code once - run everywhere“ approach of Flow makes the move from the application to the website very simple.

Whether you start with your website and build the applications from there or you have your application and need content management added to it – Neos and Flow got your back.

properties.source:
• TYPO3 Neos 1.0

    Changing the world of web content management. TYPO3 Neos 1.0 has been released.

properties.text:
Show Cases

Are you curious who is already working with Neos? Looking for a list of references for inspiration or as an argument for your next project?
We tried to identify most projects out there to give you an overview what is possible with Neos and - of course - to show you: It's time to start your own project now because Neos is ready for it.

We divided the list into two categories: "Customer" and "Agency/Usergroup" to differentiate the target groups, because customer projects are mostly requirement driven and we want to show you, that Neos can fulfill these requirements easily. "Agency/Usergroup" sites are often feature driven and at some point experimental - Neos scores here as well.

If you've finished a Neos project by yourself - don't hesitate to write an email to hello [at] neos [dot] io to get it listed here as well. We are looking forward for your submissions!

properties.title: Code Sprint June 2014
properties.teaserText: The Neos/Flow team met for another code sprint at Technische Universiteit Eindhoven (TU/e) in the Netherlands leading up to the developer days. Three days were spent focussing on improving our tools, communication, discussing organizational matters, working on upcoming features and ended with finalizing the release of 1.1. The code sprint was medium sized with 13 participants in total.
properties.author: Aske Ertmann

properties.text:
The team has been evaluating a new project management tool called Jira for some time and work went into getting the necessary steps done for being able to use it. This is still an ongoing project and more news about that will come, but so far it’s looking very promising. Issues reported in the old tracker (forge) will still be seen, but it’s encouraged to report to the new system instead. You can use your typo3.org account to log in.

Additionally the team set up new emails for neos@typo3.org and flow@typo3.org that goes directly to a service desk in Jira that several team members have access to. This is done to avoid single points of failure and to speed up response times.

To ease the review process a new automatic coding guidelines cleanup task is in the making, which check the formal style of code reviews so the developers can focus on the important parts of reviewing. Current state is available here.

Improvements for the website were discussed and certain parts were updated, including the download instructions to make them more clear. Other technical improvements were also done. Additionally the review process was discussed and how to handle it in a good way, which will help new contributors and keeping the number of open reviews limited.

Realizing that the Flow website needs a caring hand the team planned to update the Flow website based on the Neos website and work has already begun to achieve that. If anybody would be interested in helping out with this project, please get in contact with us at flow@typo3.org.

One of the main topics of the code sprint was dealing with some of organizational challenges the team are facing. The release management and process was discussed to make the task more explicit, defining and describing the process as well as the responsibilities of the release manager. You can read more about it on the website. In addition to release management the team realised the feature development workflow had to be improved. This was realised after seeing the amount of work required for releasing 1.1, which took a lot longer than anticipated. From now on new features are not allowed to go into the core unless they are documented, provide tests and include release notes. This is done to prevent a pile up of work required for finalizing a release, additionally it should improve the completeness of features.

No code sprint without working on some interesting new features. At this code sprint that included finalising placeholder support for inline editing, global content constraints, translation of the user interface, content translation, a configuration module, tabbed inspector, inspector text area editor, improving TypoScript, fine-grained access controls and many other things. Most of which have been in progress for quite some time already and still have many things to do before they’re finishing, while others managed to be finished during the code sprint. More information about the upcoming features to come.

The team put a lot of effort into finish releasing 1.1 before the developer days and could happily announce the release about an hour prior to the opening of the developer days. This was important to the team since the team had a clear goal of improving adoption by the community. Thanks to Christian Müller for effectively taking on the role of release manager of this release. You can read more about the release in the release article.

properties.caption: The team celebrating releasing 1.1 just before the developer days.

properties.text: The team got together and discussed a proposed roadmap and selected Aske Ertmann as the release manager of the upcoming 1.2 release. More information about release dates and features coming.

Out of the 13 participants, the code sprint welcomed three new first timers, including Visay Keo from Web Essentials and Dominik Stankowski, member of the EAB, both joining from Cambodia. Thanks to all the participants and a special thanks to Rens Admiraal, Patrick Broens and TU/e for organising the sprint. More details can be found on wiki page.

In addition Bastian Waidelich and Andreas Förthner had their own little code sprint remotely at the same time focussing on fine-grained access control.

There are two code sprints in the planning for the third quarter of 2014. First one will be a smaller/short one in August (25th - 31st) planned to take place in northern Germany. If you’d like to participate please write to the mailing list.

Next up is a code sprint not to be missed. Following the success of the Copenhagen code sprint in 2012 which was held on a houseboat, the team is planning a repeating the formula of having a single location that accommodates work and living arrangements. This is much more effective and also cheaper compared to renting hotel rooms. The plan is to have a large number (16-32) of participants and to have a whole week, e.g. saturday till saturday. The location will probably be somewhere in Denmark, depending on the amount of participants either in a castle or a big summer house. The location will be sponsored and depending on how many participants the travel expenses will be fully reimbursed. The sprint is planned to take place in week 40 (29/9–3/10) and to plan the event the organizers need to know who plans to participate since finding a location depends a lot on how many participants. If you’d like to participate please respond to this doodle as soon as possible. As always the team welcomes new contributors to our code sprints with one simple rule being that you have some Neos experience and can mostly work on your own. Especially contributors with frontend knowledge (JavaScript, CSS) are needed. Hope to see you there

properties.title: Code Sprint October 2014
properties.teaserText:
Between 27th of september and 5th of october nearly 30 people met in Denmark at an amazing castle to work on TYPO3 Neos.

Participants from the United States, Cambodia, Russia and all over Europe worked on several parts of the content management system with the major goals to improve the user experience, add additional features and fix bugs.
properties.author: Berit Hlubek

properties.text: Aske Ertmann organized this sprint and found a wonderful location in the south of Denmark. Lungholm Castle is a manor from 15th century with wonderfully decorated rooms and a gigantic garden. Sleeping rooms with canopy beds, libraries with several comfortable couches and armchairs, a billiard room and a monorail dining room are only a few of the specialties this location had to offer. For the first time at a code sprint we had to organize and cook all meals on our own. This led to a good team atmosphere and it was easy to get to know everyone.

Several new contributors

Next to many team members and contributors, who already participated in previous Neos code sprints, we also had seven new contributors joining for the first time: Daniel Lienert (Germany), Dmitri Pisarev (Russia), Jonas Renggli (Switzerland), Kerstin Huppenbauer (Germany), Lars Nieuwenhuizen (The Netherlands), Philipp Hanebrink (Germany) and Steffen Frosch (Germany).

In the middle of the sprint Henjo Hoeksma (The Netherlands) organized a meeting with all of the first-time participants to gather some feedback on what we can do to lower the barriers that first-time contributors face. It was a fruitful meeting; We are now looking for solutions to the barriers identified in the meeting as well as already known challenges. For example, we will reorganize the contribution page on the website and work hard to improve the Neos documentation so that all of Neos is documented.

Finalizing Neos 1.2 Beta 1

One of the major tasks of the sprint was the finalization of TYPO3 Neos 1.2 Beta 1. Aske Ertmann (Denmark), Christopher Hlubek (Germany), Sebastian Helzle (Germany), Visay Keo (Cambodia), Dmitri, Jonas, Philipp, Daniel, Markus Goldbeck (Germany) and Christian Albrecht (Germany) worked on stability improvements, bugfixes and user experience optimizations for the next release. Robert Lemke (Germany) and Karsten Dambekalns (Germany) worked on finishing the content dimensions support with bugfixes and improvements. Their efforts included work on translatable URLs and site import and export which is now fully functional. Currently we plan to release Beta 1 within the next 2-3 weeks.

In addition to the general release topics, Dominique Feyer (Switzerland) also finalized some improvements of link handling. This means that with TYPO3 Neos 1.2, shortcut pages will include a link editor for the inspector and allow linking to internal pages, to assets and to external targets, instead of just to internal pages.

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.alternativeText: Working in one of the libraries
properties.title: Working in one of the libraries

properties.text:
Translations, ACLs and documentation

A big feature which was nearly finished is the translation of the TYPO3 Neos user interface. With this change it will be possible to translate all backend labels into every possible language. Henjo, Berti Golf (Germany), Sascha Nowak (Germany), Jonas and Christopher worked on the missing parts of this feature. We are using a online service for handling the translation, making it possible for everyone to help with translating to in his/her own language. The feature will be part of the 1.3 release, however the translation can start as soon as it’s finished in the development branch, so we have a multiple languages ready by the 1.3 release date.

Another commonly requested feature is access restrictions (ACLs). Andreas Förthner (Germany) and Rens Admiraal (The Netherlands) worked on the user interface and the test coverage for ACLs. Steps like the definition of privilege types are already done and nearly fully implemented. The status of the UI integration is somewhere around 80% done and one of the major tasks which are currently being worked on is the test coverage.

Jacob Floyd (USA) and Kerstin spend some time to improve documentation. Jacob is working on an editor guide and Kerstin finalized a frontend login plugin and afterwards started cookbook entries about that plugin and other topics like routing or content cache configuration.

Several discussions

During the sprint we also had a lot of time to discuss several topics. Two of those were image editing in Neos and planning for Neos 1.3.
Berit Hlubek (Germany) started the image editing discussion. It was mainly about what image edits are currently possible when editors add them to a website, and the ideas we have to make that better in future releases. Within the discussion we defined clear rules which will build the basis of the final concept. The goal will be to adjust the user interface and integrator options to provide a better user experience when creating responsive websites.

Robert initialized the discussion about TYPO3 Neos 1.3. We discussed different contribution barriers that might exist in the Neos project and brainstormed about several feature and improvement wishes for version 1.3. During the discussion we elected Robert as release manager for that version.

And more ...

Of course these are just some of the topics that we worked on during our code sprint. Some of the other things include:

  • Switch the currently used HTML editor (node type "HTML") to CodeMirror, this brings support for several other programming languages and not only HTML (Steffen)
  • XML Sitemap creation (Dominique)
  • Automated CGL Fixing within code reviews (Lienhart Woitok, Germany)
  • Making it possible to use Ember within you own backend module (Markus, Sascha)
  • Asset sharing between websites (Lars)
  • Development toolbar (Marc Neuhaus, Germany)
  • Automated node type creation based on schema.org (Dominique)
  • Update jira.neos.io (Jacob)
  • Optimize neos.io website (Berit)
  • Everyone tried to work on moving tickets from Forge to Jira
